clean_story: Endless water.  Vanishing clues. "Oceans erase evidence" because they act like a planet-sized shredder—dissolving, scattering, and burying what falls in. A plane crashes into the sea. Saltwater corrodes metal 100x faster than air, turning aluminum into flakes in months. Currents drag debris across thousands of miles—like a puzzle tossed from a moving train. Waves pulverize wood, bones, and fabric into particles smaller than sand. The Mariana Trench’s pressure—15,000 psi—crushes objects like soda cans under a truck. Even DNA washes away:Sharks and bacteria break down flesh in days, while deep-sea worms dissolve bones in weeks. MH370’s disappearance in 2014 proved this—only 30 fragments found, none larger than a suitcase. Three related subjects are deep-sea decomposition, shipwreck preservation tricks, and how tides rewrite coastlines.
